page.title: 01SOUTH-EAST RAASAY
page.content: THIS AREA OF RAASAY IS MAINLY MOORLAND WITH BIRCH AND ALDER WOODS ALONG THE WEST COAST AND AN AREA OF FORESTRY PLANTATION TO THE EAST OF THE BLOCK. THE HILLS AND MOORLAND AREA IS USED BY THE SOUTH ISLAND SHEEP-HOLDING CLUB WHOSE MEMBERS GRAZE THEIR SHEEP ON IT. ABOUT A MILE FROM THE VILLAGE THERE IS A SHEEP FANK WHERE THE CLUB MEMBERS DIP AND SHEAR THE SHEEP. AT THE TOP OF THE GLEN ROAD THERE ARE SOME DERELECT BUILDINGS. THESE WERE PART OF AN IRON ORE MINE WHICH IS NO LONGER IN USE AND HAVE BEEN MARKED AS DANGEROUS BUILDINGS. THIS AREA OF RAASAY HAS ONLY ONE FAMILY IN PERMENANT RESIDENCE. ALONG THE EAST COAST THERE ARE FOUR HOUSES ALL BELONGING TO FAMILIES WHO ONLY USE THEM AS HOLIDAY HOMES. THERE ARE STILL SOME RUINS OF THE CROFTING COMMUNITY THAT LIVED THERE.
